head.title: World Briefing | Europe: France: First Wolf Cull Since 1930

hedline.hl1: World Briefing | Europe: France: First Wolf Cull Since 1930

abstract.p: France is authorizing killing of wolves for first time since 1930 in response to farmers who hold that more than 2,000 sheep were killed by wolves in 2003; government will allow four wolves to be killed this year (S)

block.p: In response to demands from southern farmers wanting to protect their sheep, France has authorized the killing of wolves, a protected species, for the first time since 1930. Farmers say wolves killed more than 2,000 sheep last year and decimated a flock of 140 sheep in Alpes de Haute-Provence on Saturday. France reintroduced wolves in Mercantour National Park, in southeast France, in 1992, and the colony has grown to 39 by the government's count. Farmers say there are 55. The government said it would allow four to be killed this year.
